name: Subnets, Network ACLs, and Security Groups
description: Flashcards explaining VPC segmentation and security using pizza shop metaphors

cards.front: You're designing a cloud network and want to isolate public-facing resources from internal databases. What AWS construct allows this?
cards.back: Use subnets in an Amazon VPC. Public subnets host resources with internet access, while private subnets isolate internal resources like databases.
cards.example: You place your web servers in a public subnet and RDS in a private subnet to separate access levels.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: A segment of a VPC used to isolate resources by function or access level.
A private virtual network inside AWS.

cards.front: You want to filter traffic entering and leaving a subnet, treating each packet independently. What should you use?
cards.back: Use a Network ACL (Access Control List). It acts as a stateless firewall at the subnet level, inspecting every inbound and outbound packet.
cards.example: You create a NACL to allow only HTTP and SSH traffic into your public subnet and deny all others.
cards.mnemonic: No memory. No shortcuts. Each packet checked twice.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: A stateless firewall that filters traffic at the subnet level.
Each packet is evaluated without memory of previous ones.

cards.front: You want to control access to a specific EC2 instance and automatically allow return traffic. Which tool should you use?
cards.back: Use a Security Group. It's a stateful firewall that filters inbound traffic to an EC2 instance and allows return traffic automatically.
cards.example: You configure a security group to allow HTTPS traffic to your EC2 instance; responses are allowed out automatically.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: A stateful firewall that controls traffic at the EC2 instance level.
Remembers allowed traffic and permits return responses.

cards.front: You’re configuring access controls in AWS and want layered protection—one at the subnet and another at the instance level. What combo should you use?
cards.back: Use Network ACLs for subnet-level filtering and Security Groups for instance-level control. Together they provide layered security.
cards.example: You restrict all traffic at the subnet level with NACLs and fine-tune EC2 access with security groups.
cards.mnemonic: Bouncer at the door. Doorman inside.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Controls traffic to and from an EC2 instance, statefully.
Controls traffic in/out of a subnet, statelessly.
